deliberation: Checked the prophetic introduction formula. The phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me' conceptualizes divine speech as something that can 'come' spatially, which is conventional but still figurative (personification/metonymy/idiom). No other imagery present.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: initiative and directedness of God’s communication toward the prophet
posture: authorize Ezekiel’s message as divinely initiated
authentication formula
prophetic discourse
instances.explanation: God’s message is portrayed as a 'word' that can come to someone, personifying the word and using a spatial arrival metaphor as an idiomatic way to describe revelation.

deliberation: Looked for imagery. The key phrase 'ben-’adam' is a fixed idiomatic address meaning 'human/mortal'; 'riddle' and 'parable' describe genre, not figurative content. So counted only the address as idiom/metonymy for human frailty.

instances.english_text: O mortal (lit. son of man)
ground: emphasis on Ezekiel’s human, mortal status before God
posture: humbling form of address highlighting God’s superiority
status-marking vocative
prophetic address convention
instances.explanation: The phrase literally means 'son of man' but idiomatically means 'human/mortal', using lineage language metonymically to stress Ezekiel’s humanity.

deliberation: This inaugurates the allegory. The 'great eagle' is a metaphor for a powerful king (Nebuchadnezzar), and 'the top of the cedar' is the royal apex of Judah (its king/royal house). Lebanon/cedar imagery is part of that plant-kingdom metaphor. Treated eagle and cedar-top as two distinct metaphors.

instances.hebrew_text: הַנֶּשֶׁר הַגָּדוֹל גְּדוֹל הַכְּנָפַיִם אֶרֶךְ הָאֵבֶר מָלֵא הַנּוֹצָה אֲשֶׁר־לוֹ הָרִקְמָה
instances.english_text: The great eagle with the great wings and the long pinions, with the full plumage and the brilliant colors
ground: power, far reach, majesty, ability to swoop down on prey/lands
posture: present Nebuchadnezzar as a God-used agent of overwhelming power
foreshadowing instrument of judgment
prophetic interpretation of imperial politics
instances.explanation: The richly described eagle represents the Babylonian king, emphasizing his power, reach, and splendor through avian imagery.

instances.english_text: came to the Lebanon range and seized the top of the cedar
target: Jerusalem’s royal house and its king (esp. Jehoiachin)
vehicle: Lebanon with its cedars, especially the top of a cedar tree
ground: height, prominence, and nobility of the royal house; its vulnerable topmost leader
posture: depict the removal of Judah’s king as a pruning of a lofty tree
interpret exile as divinely directed cutting down
judgment on elevated human power
instances.explanation: Lebanon’s cedar-top stands for the Davidic king in Jerusalem; the eagle seizing it pictures Nebuchadnezzar deporting the king from his high position.

deliberation: Continuing the allegory: the 'topmost shoot' still represents the removed king, and its being carried to 'land of Canaan, city of merchants' figuratively designates Babylon by a trade-focused label. Treated these as two related but distinct figurative moves: plant-part for king, commercial-land for Babylon.

instances.english_text: He plucked off its topmost bough
vehicle: the top of the young shoots of a cedar
ground: being the highest, youngest, and most prominent part, easily removed
posture: present the exile of the king as precise selective pruning
show sovereignty over the monarchy’s fate
interpret political loss in horticultural terms
instances.explanation: The 'topmost bough' image continues to depict the king as the uppermost, most prominent part of the royal tree, which the eagle can easily pluck away.

instances.english_text: to the land of traders and set it in a city of merchants
target: Babylon as the place of exile
vehicle: a land of traders, a city of merchants
ground: Babylon’s role as an international trading hub, cosmopolitan and profit-driven
posture: frame Babylon as a marketplace-dominated center rather than as a covenantal land
underscore Judah’s subjection to foreign economic-political power
critical depiction of empire
instances.explanation: Calling Babylon 'land of traders/city of merchants' uses its commercial character metonymically to identify it and to highlight its nature as an economic-imperial power.

deliberation: Still within the allegory: 'seed of the land' planted in a field represents a new, local king (Zedekiah) established by Babylon; then 'like a willow beside abundant waters' is a comparison of its placement. Treated planting as metaphor and the 'like a willow' as a simile.

instances.english_text: He then took some of the seed of the land and planted it in a fertile field
target: a native member of the royal line (Zedekiah) installed as vassal king
vehicle: seed of the land planted in a field
ground: taking local stock and establishing it in conditions meant to foster controlled growth
derivation from the land and dependence on the planter
posture: portray Zedekiah’s kingship as something carefully planted and controlled by the imperial power
stress his derivative, dependent position
interpret vassalage as cultivated planting
instances.explanation: The 'seed of the land' planted in a field is the vassal king from Judah established by Babylon, likened to locally sourced seed that is put under a gardener’s control.

instances.english_text: he planted and set it like a willow beside abundant waters
target: the newly established vassal kingdom of Judah
vehicle: water-loving tree in a favorable location
ground: having abundant resources and good conditions for growth and stability
posture: highlight that Judah had adequate conditions under Babylonian oversight to survive
undercut any excuse for seeking other support
evaluation of vassal situation as sufficient
instances.explanation: Comparing the planting to a willow beside abundant waters emphasizes that the vassal kingdom was placed in favorable conditions to live and grow.

deliberation: The seed grows into a 'spreading vine of low stature' whose branches turn toward the planter and whose roots remain under him. This is the vine-as-kingdom metaphor elaborated to portray humble growth and dependence on Babylon. Treated as a single extended plant metaphor for the vassal state.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיִּצְמַח וַיְהִי לְגֶפֶן סֹרַחַת שִׁפְלַת קוֹמָה לִפְנוֹת דָּלִיּוֹתָיו אֵלָיו וְשָׁרָשָׁיו תַּחְתָּיו יִהְיוּ
instances.english_text: It grew and became a spreading vine of low stature, [with] its twigs turning to him, and its roots staying under him
target: Judah as a vassal kingdom under Babylon (especially under Zedekiah)
vehicle: a low, spreading vine whose branches lean toward and whose roots remain beneath the planter
humble creeper dependent on its support
ground: modest size (not a tall tree), dependence, orientation of growth toward the benefactor, rootedness under his control
posture: portray the intended proper role of Judah as humbly dependent on Babylon
illustrate the acceptable but limited arrangement God allowed
explanatory allegory of vassal stability
instances.explanation: Judah’s vassal state is depicted as a low, sprawling vine whose growth is directed toward its benefactor and whose roots remain under him, illustrating planned, humble dependence.

deliberation: The second 'great eagle' stands for another powerful king (Pharaoh of Egypt), and the vine’s bending its roots and twigs toward him for water portrays Judah’s political reorientation. Treated eagle and vine’s turning as two related but distinct metaphors.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיְהִי נֶשֶׁר־אֶחָד גָּדוֹל גְּדוֹל כְּנָפַיִם וְרַב־נוֹצָה
instances.english_text: But there was another great eagle with great wings and full plumage
vehicle: another great eagle with large wings and many feathers
ground: significant power and reach, ability to project strength, attractiveness as an ally
posture: present Egypt as a seemingly attractive alternative patron to Babylon
set up contrast between competing great powers
critical framing of Judah’s temptation
instances.explanation: The second eagle represents Egypt’s king, another major power, depicted with similar majestic bird imagery to show his rival appeal.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִנֵּה הַגֶּפֶן הַזֹּאת כָּפְנָה שָׁרָשֶׁיהָ עָלָיו וְדָלִיּוֹתָיו שִׁלְחָה־לּוֹ לְהַשְׁקוֹת אוֹתָהּ
instances.english_text: and this vine now bent its roots in his direction and sent out its twigs toward him, that he might water it
target: Judah under Zedekiah seeking Egyptian support
vehicle: a vine bending its roots and stretching its tendrils toward another source of water
plant reorienting toward a different water source
ground: turning away from original benefactor to seek sustenance from another, reorienting dependence
posture: depict Judah’s appeal to Egypt as a kind of disloyal turning of roots and branches
morally critique the political maneuver
warn against misplaced trust
instances.explanation: The vine’s roots and twigs reaching toward the second eagle for water represent Judah’s political reorientation toward Egypt to seek help instead of remaining loyal to Babylon.

deliberation: Still elaborating the vine metaphor: rich soil and abundant water depict good conditions, and 'to be a noble vine' describes the intended flourishing state. Kept this as one continued metaphorical portrayal of Judah’s potential under the original arrangement.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶל־שָׂדֶה טּוֹב אֶל־מַיִם רַבִּים הִיא שְׁתוּלָה לַעֲשׂוֹת עָנָף וְלָשֵׂאת פֶּרִי לִהְיוֹת לְגֶפֶן אַדָּרֶת
instances.english_text: though it was planted in rich soil beside abundant water—so that it might grow branches and produce boughs and be a noble vine
target: Judah’s vassal kingdom as God-allowed polity under Babylon
vehicle: a vine planted in good field by many waters that can become a noble vine
ground: good external conditions for growth and fruitfulness, potential for honorable flourishing if conditions are respected
posture: stress that Judah’s initial situation under Babylon was adequate and honorable if they remained loyal
prepare for the charge that their ruin is self-inflicted
implicit admonition and explanation
instances.explanation: The well-planted vine meant to become 'noble' portrays Judah as having been given favorable conditions to grow and bear fruit under the vassal arrangement.

deliberation: Still inside the plant allegory: uprooting roots, tearing off its crown, and foliage withering all symbolize the kingdom’s downfall. Rather than split each horticultural verb, treated this as one destruction-metaphor applied to the vine/kingdom.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲלוֹא אֶת־שָׁרָשֶׁיהָ יְנַתֵּק וְאֶת־פִּרְיָהּ יְקוֹסֵס וְיָבֵשׁ כׇּל־טַרְפֵּי צִמְחָהּ תִּיבָשׁ
instances.english_text: Will he not tear out its roots and rip off its crown, so that its entire foliage withers? It shall wither
target: the vassal kingdom of Judah with its leadership and population
vehicle: a vine whose roots are torn out, crown stripped, and foliage dried up
ground: radical removal of stability (roots), removal of leadership/fruit, complete loss of vitality
posture: warn that rebellion will bring total dismantling of Judah’s polity despite human efforts
undercut false hopes of survival
prophetic threat of judgment
instances.explanation: The imagery of tearing out roots, stripping the crown, and withering foliage depicts the complete overthrow and desiccation of Judah’s vassal kingdom and its benefits.

deliberation: Examined the 'east wind' and withering language. In prophetic usage, the 'east wind' is a stock image for scorching, destructive force, often linked to divine judgment. The withering of the plant under this wind continues the kingdom-as-vine metaphor, foregrounding the east wind as a figurative agent of ruin.

instances.hebrew_text: כְגַעַת בָּהּ רוּחַ הַקָּדִים תִּיבַשׁ יָבֹשׁ
instances.english_text: When the east wind strikes it, it shall wither—wither
target: the destructive intervention against Judah (esp. Babylon’s assault as God’s instrument)
vehicle: the scorching east wind that causes a plant to wither
ground: sudden, intense, and inescapable drying and killing effect
overpowering external force that a plant cannot resist
posture: depict God’s chosen instrument of judgment as a harsh natural force that guarantees Judah’s ruin
stress inevitability of withering despite good planting
warning and explanation
instances.explanation: The 'east wind' represents the harsh, divinely directed historical force (Babylonian invasion) that will cause the vassal kingdom, pictured as a plant, to wither and die.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as verse 1. Again the 'word of YHWH came to me' phrase uses movement language for speech. Treated it as the same conventional personification/metonymy/idiom, with no other imagery in the verse.

instances.english_text: Then the word of GOD came to me
ground: God’s initiative and directedness in sending a message
posture: reaffirm divine origin of the explanation that follows
mark transition and authority
prophetic discourse convention
instances.explanation: The phrase again personifies God’s speech as a 'word' that travels and arrives, an idiomatic way to describe the experience of receiving revelation.

deliberation: Here the allegory is unpacked in largely literal historical terms. The main non-literal element is the label 'house of rebellion' or 'rebellious breed' for Israel, which is a figurative characterization of the people by a defining trait. Treated that as a metaphorical epithet.

instances.english_text: to the rebellious breed (lit. house of rebellion)
target: the people of Israel/Judah as a community
vehicle: lineage/household characterized by a single trait
ground: persistent, defining rebellion as if it were their family identity or household name
posture: sharply denounce the audience’s character, framing rebellion as their core identity
heighten culpability and shame
prophetic rebuke
instances.explanation: Calling Israel the 'house of rebellion' metaphorically treats rebelliousness as their family name and defining characteristic, in a somewhat hyperbolic moral indictment.

deliberation: Narration of historical actions: taking from the 'seed of the kingship' (royal offspring) is expressed with 'seed' for descendants—a standard Hebrew metaphor/metonymy. The rest is covenantal/legal language used literally. So I marked only 'seed of the kingship' as figurative.

instances.english_text: one of the seed royal
target: a member of the royal family
ground: origin in a line, continuity and propagation from a source
posture: stress dynastic continuity even in political humiliation
frame the selected vassal as legitimate offspring of the monarchy
historical explanation with genealogical nuance
instances.explanation: The phrase uses 'seed' as a metonymic/idiomatic expression for descendants, portraying the royal line in terms of reproductive seed.

deliberation: Looked for conceptual metaphors. The 'low kingdom' and 'not exalt itself' use vertical height for status/pride, which is a standard metaphorical mapping. Treated the height language as one figurative complex for humility vs. self-exaltation.

instances.english_text: so that it might be a humble kingdom and not exalt itself
target: the status and behavior of the vassal kingdom of Judah
vehicle: being low vs. exalting oneself (height imagery)
ground: low height as humility/subordination; highness/exaltation as pride and overreaching power
status hierarchy mapped onto vertical scale
power and arrogance vs. modest submission
posture: define God’s will that Judah remain in a low, submissive posture rather than seek greatness
moralize political realism as humility
didactic use of spatial metaphor
instances.explanation: Describing the kingdom as 'low' and warning it not to 'exalt itself' uses vertical position as a metaphor for humble vs. proud political stance.

deliberation: This verse is straightforward historical and rhetorical: rebellion, sending envoys, horses, people, covenants, and escaping are all literal. The rhetorical questions heighten effect but are not figurative per se. I did not find distinct metaphors or idioms needing classification.

Considered 'As I live' and oath language. Within Israelite theology, God as 'living' is literal, and the rest of the verse is descriptive (place of the king, Babylon, dying). The verse argues judicially rather than by image, so I did not count figurative devices here.

Siege warfare is described with 'mounds' and 'siege-towers,' which are literal. No metaphorical or personifying language beyond ordinary military description. Thus no distinct figurative instance identified.

The key expression 'he gave his hand' is a standard idiom for pledging or swearing allegiance. That and possibly 'flouted an oath' are non-literal uses of physical/body language for agreement. I treated 'gave his hand' as one idiomatic/metonymic expression.

instances.english_text: he gave his promise (lit. he gave his hand)
target: the act of swearing loyalty or entering a binding agreement
ground: the hand as the organ of grasping, sealing agreements, and performing gestures; the gesture stands for the pledge
posture: underscore the seriousness of the commitment Zedekiah violated
heighten his guilt for breaking a solemnly signaled oath
legal-moral indictment
instances.explanation: The phrase 'gave his hand' is an idiom where the physical gesture of extending the hand stands metonymically for entering into a binding promise.

deliberation: Focused on 'I will give it upon his head' as a figurative way of saying 'I will make it fall back on him' (punitive reversal). Considered the oath 'As I live' but again treated that as standard formula. Marked the 'on his head' expression as a retributive metaphor/idiom.

instances.hebrew_text: אָֽלָתִי אֲשֶׁר בָּזָה וּבְרִיתִי אֲשֶׁר הֵפִיר וּנְתַתִּיו בְּרֹאשׁוֹ
instances.english_text: My oath which he flouted and My covenant which he broke—I will pay him back (lit. I will give it upon his head)
target: the personal experience of punishment by the covenant-breaker
vehicle: placing something on a person’s head
burden or blow descending upon the head
ground: the head as the top/most exposed part; something coming 'on the head' as bearing the brunt of consequences
consequences returning directly onto the offender
posture: assert that the broken oath and covenant will recoil back on the violator himself
underline strict, personal retribution by God
judgment declaration
instances.explanation: The phrase 'I will give it upon his head' metaphorically portrays God’s retribution as something placed on the offender’s head, indicating consequences falling back on him.

deliberation: Here God’s capture of the king is portrayed through hunting/fishing imagery: spreading a net and catching him in a snare. This is a clear metaphor for God’s providential seizure using historical means. Treated the net/snare complex as one extended metaphor.

instances.english_text: I will spread My net over him and he shall be caught in My snare
target: the king who broke the covenant being inexorably captured and judged
vehicle: a net and snare used to trap prey
ground: inescapable entanglement, loss of freedom, being overtaken by a hidden but effective device
sudden and total capture beyond the prey’s control
posture: present God as the true hunter/ensnarer behind political events
emphasize the inescapability of judgment
reassure that covenant-breaking will be pursued
instances.explanation: God’s action in arresting the covenant-breaking king is depicted as spreading a net and catching him in a snare, a vivid metaphor of inescapable capture.

deliberation: Saw three figurative elements: (1) 'all his fugitives in all his wings' with 'wings' for divisions or extensions of his forces; (2) 'fall by the sword' using 'sword' as metonymy for violent death/war; (3) 'scatter to every wind' as a dispersal image functioning like a merism for all directions. Treated these as three distinct instances.

instances.english_text: And all the fugitives of all his battalions (lit. in all his wings)
target: the king’s various military units and outlying contingents
vehicle: appendages or outstretched limbs of a bird/body
ground: peripheral extensions branching out from a central body, capable of flight/escape
posture: indicate that not only the king but all his far-flung forces will be brought down
stress the totality of collapse
judgment on the entire military apparatus
instances.explanation: Referring to his 'wings' depicts his forces or outlying groups as extensions like a bird’s wings, metonymic for all parts of his power structure.

instances.english_text: shall fall by the sword
target: the violent deaths of his fugitives in war
ground: the sword as the standard weapon typifying warfare and execution
posture: announce that escapees will die in battle, not survive
underscore unavoidable violent end
judgment oracle
instances.explanation: The 'sword' stands metonymically for warfare and violent death; to 'fall by the sword' is an idiomatic way of saying they will be killed in war.

instances.english_text: and those who remain shall scatter in every direction (lit. to every wind they shall be scattered)
target: the surviving remnant of the king’s people
vehicle: debris blown by winds in all directions
ground: forcible, chaotic dispersal with no control and no single direction
total displacement and loss of cohesion
posture: warn that any survivors will be utterly scattered among the nations
stress completeness of dispersion
judgment and loss of national coherence
instances.explanation: Being scattered 'to every wind' metaphorically portrays the survivors as blown in all directions, a vivid image of complete and uncontrollable dispersal.

deliberation: God resumes the arboreal imagery but now as positive promise: taking from the 'top of the high cedar', plucking a tender twig, planting it on a high mountain. Within the chapter’s mapping, the cedar is the Davidic dynasty and the tender twig a future ruler; the mountain stands for an exalted Zion. I distinguished three related metaphors: cedar-top, tender twig, and high mountain.

instances.hebrew_text: וְלָקַחְתִּי אָנִי מִצַּמֶּרֶת הָאֶרֶז הָרָמָה וְנָתָתִּי
instances.english_text: Then I in turn will take and set [in the ground a slip] from the lofty top of the cedar
target: the Davidic royal house from which God will select
vehicle: the lofty top of a high cedar
uppermost part of a tall tree
ground: elevated, distinguished origin; the top as the select portion from a noble tree
posture: affirm God’s ongoing claim on and use of the Davidic line despite present judgment
introduce a new, hopeful divine initiative
restoration promise
instances.explanation: The 'lofty top of the cedar' stands for the Davidic dynasty in its elevated status, from which God will take a portion for His purpose.

instances.english_text: I will pluck a tender twig from the tip of its crown
target: a future chosen ruler from the Davidic house
individual messianic figure or renewed leadership
vehicle: a tender young shoot from the top of the tree
ground: youth, newness, vulnerability yet potential for growth, close connection to noble source
fresh beginning from the same stock
posture: depict the awaited ruler as a new, delicate yet promising offshoot
encourage hope in gentle but divinely planted leadership
restorative vision
instances.explanation: The 'tender twig' is a young offshoot from the cedar’s crown symbolizing a future Davidic ruler—new, vulnerable, but full of potential.

instances.english_text: and I will plant it on a tall, towering mountain
target: the exalted position of the renewed kingdom centered in Zion/Israel
vehicle: a tall, towering mountain where a tree is planted
ground: visibility, prominence, stability, and exaltation associated with a high mountain
posture: promise that the new Davidic plant will be set in an exalted, prominent place by God Himself
reverse earlier lowering of Judah
hopeful elevation
instances.explanation: Planting the tender twig on a 'tall, towering mountain' metaphorically portrays God exalting the restored kingdom and its ruler to a prominent, secure position.

deliberation: The planted twig becomes a 'noble cedar', and 'every bird of every feather' shelters in its shade—standard prophetic imagery for an exalted kingdom providing refuge for many nations. I treated (1) the noble cedar as the restored kingdom and (2) the birds under its shade as dependent peoples/nations.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָשָׂא עָנָף וְעָשָׂה פֶרִי וְהָיָה לְאֶרֶז אַדִּיר
instances.english_text: and it shall bring forth boughs and produce branches and grow into a noble cedar
target: the future restored kingdom centered on God’s chosen ruler
vehicle: a great cedar tree with many branches and fruit
ground: strength, stability, height, and expansive reach; capacity to support others and be fruitful
posture: present the restored Davidic realm as strong and life-giving, not low and withering
offer a positive counter-image to earlier withering vine
hope and reassurance
instances.explanation: The twig becoming a 'noble cedar' depicts the restored kingdom as a majestic, fruitful tree with expansive reach and stability.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשָׁכְנוּ תַחְתָּיו כׇּל־צִפּוֹר כׇּל־כָּנָף בְּצֵל דָּלִיּוֹתָיו תִּשְׁכֹּנָּה
instances.english_text: Every bird of every feather shall take shelter under it, shelter in the shade of its boughs
target: the various nations/peoples benefiting from and subject to the restored kingdom
those who find refuge under God’s rule
vehicle: all kinds of birds dwelling under a tree’s branches and in their shade
ground: protection, shade, and habitat provided by a large tree to many different creatures
posture: portray the restored kingdom as a source of shelter and stability for many peoples
anticipate a broad, inclusive impact
expansive eschatological hope
instances.explanation: The many birds dwelling under the cedar’s shade represent diverse peoples or nations finding refuge and shelter under the rule of the exalted kingdom.

deliberation: The verse generalizes the arboreal imagery: 'all the trees of the field' are other powers, and God’s actions—abasing the high tree, exalting the low tree, drying the green, making the dry flourish—use tree health/height as metaphors for status and prosperity. Treated this as one overarching metaphor of trees as human powers and God’s reversal of fortunes.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָדְעוּ כׇּל־עֲצֵי הַשָּׂדֶה כִּי אֲנִי יְהוָה הִשְׁפַּלְתִּי עֵץ גָּבֹהַּ הִגְבַּהְתִּי עֵץ שָׁפָל הוֹבַשְׁתִּי עֵץ לָח וְהִפְרַחְתִּי עֵץ יָבֵשׁ
instances.english_text: Then shall all the trees of the field know that it is I, GOD, who have abased the lofty tree and exalted the lowly tree, who have dried up the green tree and made the withered tree bud
target: human kingdoms, powers, and individuals whose status God reverses
the realm of human status and prosperity
vehicle: trees of the field—high vs. low, green vs. dry
ground: tree height for status; greenness for prosperity; dryness for barrenness; God’s power to reverse each condition
reversibility of fortunes under divine sovereignty
humbling and exalting, killing and reviving
posture: assert God’s universal sovereignty over raising and lowering powers
interpret coming historical reversals as acts of YHWH
theological explanation and admonition
instances.explanation: Trees—especially high/low and green/dry—stand for human powers and fortunes; God’s action in lowering, raising, drying, and making flourish depicts His sovereign reversal of human status.
